Graphical abstract Typical illustration of the role of M-support interaction, M-M interaction, coordination environment, and spin states on the ORR activity of atomically precise MNx catalysts. Inspired by molecular catalysts, researchers developed atomically precise nitrogen-coordinated single or dual metal sites imbedded in graphitized carbon (M-N-C) to fully utilize metallic sites for O2 activation. These catalysts performed remarkably well in the electrocatalytic oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) due to their distinct coordination and electrical structures. Nonetheless, their maximum efficacy in practical applications has yet to be achieved. This agenda identifies tailoring the coordination environment, spin states, intersite distance, and metal–metal interaction as innovative approaches to regulate the ORR performance of these catalysts. However, it is necessary to undertake a precise assessment of these methodologies and the knowledge obtained to be implemented in the design of future M-N-C catalysts for ORR. Therefore, this review aims to analyze recent progress in M-N-C ORR catalysts, emphasizing their innovative engineering with aspects such as alteration in intersite distance, metal–metal interaction, coordination environment, and spin states. Additionally, we critically discuss how to logically monitor the atomic structure, local coordination, spin, and electronic states of M-N-C catalysts to modulate their ORR activity. We have also highlighted the challenges associated with M-N-C catalysts and proposed suggestions for their future design and fabrication. Keywords Electrocatalysis M-N-C electrocatalysts ORR Activity descriptors Spin states 1 Introduction 1.1 Motivation with electrocatalytic O2-activation Since the early 20th century, there has been a strong connection between the need for energy and technological advancements, leading to the development of new ways for converting different energy resources [1,2]. For example, the latent energy in the chemical bonds of tiny molecules such as H2 and O2 can be transformed into clean energy (in the form of electricity) by electro-activating such molecules to meet modern society’s energy demands. This agenda expects H2-O2 fuel cells (FCs) and metal-air batteries (MABs) to solve the problem of chemical energy conversion and storage, respectively [3,4] (Fig. 1 (a, b)). However, the slow kinetics of their cathode process, specifically the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), necessitate the use of promising electrocatalysts [5,6]. Although catalysts based on Pt have been in use for a long time for ORR [7,8], there is still a need to improve their limited performance, as well as reduce their cost or replace them with non-noble metal [9–11]. Typically, ORR can take place at the cathode surface through either the 4e− pathway, which directly reduces O2 into H2O, or the 2e− pathway, which includes the formation of H2O2. It has been thought that the 2e− ORR is a negative side effect that hinders the efficient 4e− ORR in H2-O2 FCs because it destroys the Nafion membrane and hence lowers the overall FC’s performance [12]. A lot of industries are now interested in using the selective 2e− pathway to electrochemically produce H2O2. For instance, bleaching pulp and textiles, treating wastewater and ballast water, and pharmaceutical and polymer industries are just a few of the many uses for H2O2 due to its strong oxidizing properties and lack of environmental toxicity [13]. One way to avoid problems with the anthraquinone process is to use electrochemical H2O2 production, which allows for continuous on-site manufacture of diluted H2O2. To make H2O2 electrosynthesis work, electrode catalysts must be created that can boost the selective 2e– ORR while lowering the competitive 4e– ORR [14,15]. This article aims to emphasize the advancements in 4e− ORR by utilizing cost-effective and efficient electrocatalysts for the development of the energy sector; therefore, we briefly introduce the importance of 2e− ORR herein. 1.2 ORR electrocatalyst with desirable features There are two different arrangements of oxygen that can be adsorbed on the active site of catalysts during the ORR process. In the first type of adsorption, referred to as dissociative side-on adsorption, the bond length between the molecules rises and the strength of the oxygen double bond decreases, leading to the formation of H2O as the byproduct. In the second type of adsorption, referred to as associative end-on adsorption, oxygen is adsorbed in the form of *OOH, which can further convert into either H2O2 or H2O. The *OOH dissociation pathway, believed to be the dominant mechanism for the ORR in acidic conditions, can be described as follows [16,17]. (1) O 2 g + ∗ → O 2 ∗ (2) O 2 ∗ + H + + e - → O O H ∗ (3) O O H ∗ + H + + e - → O H ∗ + H 2 O (4) O ∗ + H + + e - → O H ∗ (5) O H ∗ + H + + e - → H 2 O In this process, the O2 adsorbs on the active site of the catalyst, and subsequently undergo protonation to generate *OOH. Protonation and the breaking of the OO bond convert *OOH into H2O and *O. Protonating oxygen will ultimately yield H2O. However, ORR in alkaline media follows the subsequent stages [18,19]. (6) O 2 g + ∗ → O 2 ∗ (7) O 2 ∗ + H 2 O l + e - → O O H ∗ + OH - (8) O O H ∗ + e - → O ∗ + O H - (9) O ∗ + H 2 O l + e - → O H ∗ + OH - (10) O H ∗ + e - → ∗ + O H - In order to have a better understanding of the catalyst’s ORR mechanism, it is advantageous to be aware of the Gibbs free energy associated with each individual step. The rate-determining step is the transition that leads to the most significant alteration in free energy. The ORR free energy diagrams provide the limiting reaction barrier, crucial for the catalytic properties of electrocatalysts. The equation for calculating the free energy of the ORR intermediates, based on the thermodynamic model proposed by Nørekov et al., is ΔG = ΔE + ΔZPE − TΔS + ΔE solvation. Here, ΔE represents the reaction energy obtained from density-functional theory calculations, ΔZPE refers to the zero point energy, and ΔS represents the change in entropy [18,20,21]. Another crucial indicator is the overpotential (Z) and minimizing overpotential (Z) during electrocatalytic reaction [22,23] is the key aspect in selecting the most suitable material for a specific reaction. Through the calculation of the relative stability of adsorbed intermediates via exploitation of the computational hydrogen model, researchers can predict Z in any electrocatalytic reaction [24,25]. Limiting potential (U lim) for the rate-determining step, derived from the adsorbed intermediate’s energy difference, can be utilized to get the value of Z as ƞ = U eq . - U lim . The U eq stands for equilibrium potential and can be considered as constant in specific electrochemical reactions. Thus, the purpose of getting Z, can lead to minimizing U lim, or optimization of adsorbed reaction intermediate’s binding strength. According to the “Sabatier theory”, the binding strength of adsorbed species with a surface is the essential factor for a desirable catalyst. It should neither be too strong to prevent the desorption of adsorbed O-species, nor be too weak to disfavor O2-activation [26,27]. Generally, the thermodynamic energy scaling relationship can be exploited to link the adsorbed reaction intermediates on the catalyst surface [28,29]. For ORR intermediates (*O, *OOH, and *OH), the scaling relationship (ΔG (*OOH) = ΔG (*OH) + 3.2 eV (Fig. 1c)) is able to predict the ORR activity trends on various low indexed metal active sites, metal alloys and oxides (Fig. 1d) [30]. In addition, such linear scaling correlation in combination with Brønsted–Evans–Polanyi relationship between activation and reaction energies for surface reactions offers the complete energy diagram, which is capable of predicting maximum reaction rate and promising catalysts [31,32]. The scaling relationships and computational hydrogen electrode in combination are capable of predicting the optimal electrocatalyst for specific reactions with a smaller number of dependable variables, imposing a thermodynamic limitation on the catalyst. The principal aspect of volcano curves is to represent 0.86 V as the maximum limiting potential. Therefore, the minimum z value of 0.37 V was calculated using ƞ = U eq - U lim . , considering U eq = 1.23 for every elemental step. On the other hand, if adsorbed reaction species are capable to interact with various active sites of surface, circumventing the scaling relationship maybe allowed [33–37]. Considering this prospect, a new equation i.e. ΔG (*OOH) = ΔG (*OH) + 2.41 eV was proposed by Jiang et al. For example, considering the di-atomic sites model, this correlation appears to be nearly close to ΔG (*OOH) = ΔG (*OH) + 2.46 eV [38]. This novel correlation provided 1.04 V as the maximum limiting potential and succeeded in proving the utility of a multi-atomic cluster to break the scaling relationship. An ideal catalyst is supposed to offer the maximum number of exposed active sites as well as optimum intrinsic activity per site, which facilitates the electrocatalytic reaction [39–41]. 1.3 Atomically precise M-N-C catalysts In order to maximize activity and product selectivity, several electrocatalytic systems, some of which are heterogeneous (made of solid-state materials) and others of which are homogeneous (containing molecular complexes), have typically been investigated. In a homogeneous system, substrate conversion is usually catalyzed by freely diffusing species, which offer tunability and easy characterization for mechanistic knowledge [4,44]. However, molecular complexes have the disadvantages of under-utilization, de-activation, and sluggish e - transfer. Moreover, their poor solubility (in common solvents), as well as recyclability restrict them to be used on a practical scale. In contrast, the solid-state material is more favorable for electrocatalysis, having the advantage of diversity in their preparation, characterization, and mechanistic details [45]. Immobilization of molecular species directly on the electrode is one way to bridge homogenous and heterogenous catalysis. Heterogenous catalysts are capable of improving activity as well as turning over several orders via improved electron transfer kinetics as well as overall catalyst utilization [4,46]. Moreover, the active site’s isolation to avoid its de-activation can be approached by controlling the catalyst’s loading or catalyst immobilization on support, which also hinders the side reactions, including the catalyst’s dimerization or poisoning. Among these approaches, immobilization of molecular catalysts on support is the easiest protocol, which involves the non-covalent interaction (Vander Waals and pi-pi stacking) with electrode material, with several catalysts leaching to poor activity at long-term electrocatalysis [4,47–49]. To address this issue, covalent immobilization like electro-polymerization can be an effective approach, in which molecular catalysts can be stacked on the electrode’s surface directly via self-assembly and diazonium bonding [50,51]. However, in such a type of engineering, the active sites remain buried within the densely packed catalyst’s film and cannot be accessed from the substrate [45]. In spite of such advancements, the anchoring of molecular systems on electrode surfaces is still less favorable due to the poor loading of active sites and poor electronic conductivity, which limit their catalytic activity as well as durability [52]. To address these issues, catalysts’s development, having atomically precise active sites and a solid-state nature, is one of the best options for the concerned scientific community. Approaching this aspect of material design could improve not only the catalytic performance but also the selectivity of the metal nanoparticles (MNPs) by reducing their size to a single atom and then isolating the catalyst [53–56]. According to the Kubo’s equation ( δ = 4 ε / 3 N , where δ , ε , and N are the band gap, Fermi level energy, and atom number in the MNPs, respectively) [57], the electronic structures of active metal species may shift from continuous bulk valence bands to discrete HOMO-LUMO states when their sizes shrink. Based on previous studies [58–60], it was predicted that MNPs (42 nm) could have a valence band that is reasonably continuous, similar to bulk materials. Then, so-called sub-nano materials can display a highly discrete state with a narrow bandgap for metal nanoparticles smaller than 1 nm. Particles enter a distinct HOMO-LUMO state when shrunk to the cluster dimension, and environmental factors may influence their electronic states (Fig. 1e) [42]. Within this framework, atomically precise N-coordinated metal sites incorporated into carbon matrix (M-N-C) catalysts have been considered as bridges between homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts. These electrocatalysts provide buried molecular active sites (like MNx moieties) more accessible than other immobilized molecular MNx catalysts via putting catalytic moieties in metal nodes or organic struts, the active space can be isolated site as well as have uniform distribution throughout the framework [45]. The robustness of molecular active site in M-N-C catalysts gets increased due to its structural rigidity and solid-state nature. Moreover, this isolated MNx site possesses redox features similar to molecular MNx sites due to distinct frontier energy levels, highest occupied and lowest unoccupied molecular orbitals (HOMO and LUMO). The role of atomically precise MNx moieties as the active center has been known for the last few decades in homogeneous catalysts, while in heterogeneous electrocatalysis, it has been known since the last 20 years [1]. Since the introduction of atomically precise catalysts surfaced in 2011 [1], extensive efforts are made to make single-atom catalysts (SACs) as a new active area in heterogeneous electrocatalysis. The M-N-C moieties are likely to accumulate advantages of homogenous and heterogeneous catalysis to connect both sub-fields via a conceptual bridge. The deposited MNx active sites do have a different bonding environment than constituent atoms in NPs. Moreover, tuning of the electronic structure of atomically precise single atom sites may be done via nearby bonding atoms through strong M-support electronic communication or confinement [61]. In heterogenous catalysis, the use of atomically precise MNx site having the configuration of single atomic catalysts (SACs), and dual-atomic catalysts (DACs) offers a new way to utilize maximum efficiency along with helping the surrounding environment as well as displaying distinct catalytic activity in various reactions. Although this class of catalysts displayed remarkable activity, selectivity, and durability, they still suffer from the linear scaling relationship of ORR intermediates. Therefore, to achieve their ideal performance, a lot of approaches (bifunctionality, addition of promoters, functionalization of the surface via ligands, electrolyte and solvent engineering, interfacial sites, and confinement) have been experimented with to overcome the ORR linear scaling restriction (Fig. 1e). But still their ideal performance is yet to come. 1.4 The knowledge gap and scope With the unprecedented growth of atomically precise catalysts, a good number of excellent reviews are also reported covering various aspects like chemical synthesis [62], surface coordination chemistry [63], micro-environ modulation, the complete elemental diversity of periodic table [64], as well as applications of atomically precise catalysts in various reaction [64–68]. Li et al. offered excellent reviews on theoretical calculations on diverse applications as well as properties of atomically precise catalysts, SACs in particular, along with their stability and catalytic performance [69]. All these articles offered summaries full of insights, comments, and an in-depth understanding of both the state-of-the-art and future prospects of atomically precise catalysts. Nevertheless, there has not been a systematic discussion of the precise impacts of the substrate, the types of atoms in the first and second coordination shells, and the electronic configurations of the central metal atom on the ORR activity of these electrocatalysts. Besides, the precise identification of intersite distance, M-M interaction, and coordination environment for the atomically precise M-N-C catalysts to develop activity descriptors for ORR is not properly understood. Such a knowledge gap towards critical evaluation motivates us to work on this review. The prime focus of this review is to offer a rational article on atomically precise M-N-C materials for electrocatalytic ORR process and to succeed in gaining a true understanding of the structural and configurational effects on ORR activity of MNx-C moieties having the features of M-support as well as M-M interactions and intersite distances. At the end, the controversial issues of the present simulation of atomically precise catalysts, along with limitations, are critically included, with the aim of inspiring new ideas for further aspects of rational design and an in-depth basic understanding of atomically precise ORR catalysts [70]. 2 Fundamental chemistry and identification of M-N-C active sites To comprehend the coordination chemistry of atomically precise M-N-C catalytic moieties, it is imperative to examine the local structure of M-N-C sites and identify them through the use of modern characterization techniques. This section focuses on the analysis of the atomic structure and electrical configuration of the M-N-C catalytic moieties and their impact on the electrocatalytic ORR. In addition, we emphasized the systematic examination of identifying M-N-C active sites through a comprehensive investigation of both experimental and theoretical findings. 2.1 Coordination structure, adsorption and ligand binding with metal site The most common coordination structures for metal sites are tetrahedral (Td), planar 4-fold (square planar), and octahedral (Oh). The coordination of the supported or embedded isolated metal site can be saturated by adsorbing a different number of ligands if its coordination is less. Even when they are not actively participating in reactions, multi-adsorbed species can nevertheless have a significant influence on how well the reaction turns out overall. For instance, when an electrocatalytic N2 reduction reaction (NRR) occurs on SACs, one N2 molecule adsorbed on the active site is followed by an end-on or side-on configuration. In contrast, research has shown that certain 3-fold-coordinated SACs are capable of efficiently capturing 2 or 3 N2 molecules, which could change the selectivity and activity towards electrocatalytic NRR due to the multi-adsorption of N2. The adsorption of reaction intermediates on both sides must also be measured for 2D materials, having buried isolated M-N-C sites in sp2 hybridized carbon sheets. For these materials, axial adsorption of *OH or *O2 on another side of isolated M-N-C sites containing sp2 hybridized carbon sheets was hypothesized to boost ORR activity [71,72]. 2.2 Proximity in isolate active sites, neighbouring atoms, and support The modulation effect shows promise towards the enhancement of catalytic performance of atomically precise M-N-C materials. The inclusion of neighboring single-atom sites (diatomic sites) is generally recognized as a means to achieve synergistic effects, which can be harnessed to regulate the catalytic activity of inherent active sites in atomically precise catalysts. However, conducting a comprehensive investigation on this effect for atomically dispersed diatomic or multi-atomic sites is still a significant issue [70]. Within M-N-C SACs, the catalytic reaction might take place at any of the nearby atomic sites in addition to the central M-site. Because, in these catalysts, N-doped carbon matrixes act as favorable support for hosting the metal sites as active sites for the ORR process. This N-doped carbon support can also cause nearby effects due to the appropriate size and electronegativity of the N atom, which allows for the modulation of the electrical characteristics of carbon materials [73]. Therefore, the presence of N atoms can enhance the catalytic activity of carbon by generating a partial positive charge on neighboring carbon atoms (electrophilic carbon). This positive charge promotes the adsorption of nucleophilic O-species on electrophilic carbon atoms, facilitating the catalytic process. Under such circumstances, the active sites in single-atom catalysts are located on the second coordination layer of carbon rather than on the metal atoms themselves. For example, the C-atoms in the subsequent coordination shell and Fe atoms in the middle of the Fe-pyrrolic-N-C catalyst were suggested as possible active sites for the ORR process to occur via the 4e− pathway due to the improved number of active sites [74]. In addition to its function as an active site, the incidence of near atoms can also influence the ORR selectivity. In the case of a Co-N-C catalyst, for instance, the Co site would serve as the ORR’s active center, and the predominant product would be water if four pyridinic-N atoms were coordinated to it in the first shell. On the other hand, when O atoms partially substitute the coordinated atoms in the initial coordination shell, as in Co-N2O2, the active center moves to the carbon atoms adjacent to the O atoms, and H2O2 is the main product [75]. Recently, it is suggested that the core SA catalytic site and the neighboring atom to work together as active sites in a catalytic OER process. For instance, a dual-site OER mechanism on Ni-pyridinic-N4 was proposed [76]. Where, Ni atom in the middle is the preferred site for adsorption for the O atoms, forming *O-O and *OH species. A synergistic relationship between Ni sites and neighboring C-atom enabled the OER to be achieved effectively. The obligatory limiting potential was reduced as a result of this shift in the adsorption sites. It is currently unknown how the relocation stage affects the overall OER rate, however it is anticipated that the active site for *O relocation from Ni to C-site during the formation of *OOH will overcome an energy barrier. To get a deep insight into this phenamenon, it might be required to conduct detailed kinetic investigations instead of just comparing the limiting-potentials. Recently, Li et al. [77] created Ni/Co diatomic sites anchored on N-doped C-matrix (NiCo DASs/N-C) to demonstrate the proximity electronic effect for synergistic promoting electrocatalytic ORR (Fig. 2 (a–d)). The NiCo DASs/N-C catalyst demonstrates excellent activity towards ORR due to the beneficial proximity electronic effect of the nearby Ni-N4 moiety, which is anchored by four nitrogen atoms (Fig. 2(e–g)). In situ characterization results indicate that the main active site for the adsorption and activation of O2 is the Co-N4 site, where cobalt is anchored by four nitrogen atoms, as also supported by theoretical calculations (Fig. 2h). This accelerated the *OOH formation and *OH removal at the active site, and therefore enhanced the overall kinetics of this multielectron reaction. Theoretical calculations showed that the Ni-N4 site acted as a modulator, and modified the electronic structure of nearby Co-N4 moiety. This modulation promotes the *OH desorption from the Co-N4 moiety, boosting the ORR process (Fig. 2(i, j)). With the help of neighboring single-atom moieties, this research proposes a novel method for manipulating the electronic characteristics of catalytic active sites. Additionally, it offers direction for the creation of highly efficient bifunctional electrocatalysts that may be utilized in a variety of environments. Possibly new opportunities in atomically precise bi-metallic systems (e.g., Fe-Cu and Ni-Cu) could be better understood and valued with the help of modern theoretical approaches (like density-functional theory (DFT), micro-kinetic modeling, and machine learning) [78]. Several parameters, like an atomic number as well as the radius of embedded M-site, entire e−-count, e−-affinity, electronegativity, hetero-atom doping, and C-defects, have been demonstrated to influence ORR activity of bi-metallic systems. In this context, to clarify and determine the structure–function connections for a bi-metallic Fe-Ni-N-C catalyst (Ni(N3)-Fe(N3)-Cn), the partial density of states of Fe and Ni sites on C-matrix was simulated [79]. Specifically, in comparison to Fe-N4 and Ni-N4, the energies of the Fe 3d and Ni 3d orbitals in Ni(N3)-Fe(N3)-Cn arrangement changed from higher to lower levels, as also supported by the down-shift in Ni 2p and Fe 2p state’s binding energy during the XPS scan of Ni(N3)-Fe(N3)-Cn catalyst. As a result, the phenomena proved that the Ni and Fe sites worked in tandem to maximize binding affinity for the reactants and O-intermediates [80,81]. Hence, a close connection characterized by strong e−-coupling was achieved through the creation of dual-sites, most likely as a result of a cooperative synergy of the dual-metal structure (to be revealed in due course) [82]. In addition, it was found that ΔGHO* and ΔGHOO* have a well-established linear scaling relationship, meaning that ΔGHO* can be used as a universal descriptor for the ORR efficiency on catalysts with dual sites. Further, they suggested a novel OH-ligand self-binding method to study electrocatalytic ORR processes and determine the promotional impact of Fe-Co dual sites [83]. The local electron density around Fe atoms was reduced (Fig. 2k) and FeO bonding was weakened (Fig. 2l) upon introduction of the FeCoN5-OH site. In addition, ORR activity is enhanced because the scission of the elongated OO bond is promoted, which speeds up the reaction (Fig. 2m). All things considered, building structures with two sites is a great chance to change the electrical and geometric configurations of the active moieties and revise our understanding of the atomic-level reaction processes. Overall, the electronic and coordination structures of atomically precise catalysts are affected by their atomic structural changes and local coordination via orbital’s mixing and charge transfer. Also, the physicochemical characteristics of the hybrid materials could vary due to significant changes in the substrate’s electronic structure brought about by metal site insertion. The electronic structure of these catalysts can be theoretically evaluated with the use of DFT computations. Thermodynamic and kinetic investigations into the intrinsic characteristics and catalytic performance of hybrid materials are possible with the use of rational structure modeling. Moreover, the high flexibility and tunability of atomically precise M-N-C catalysts offer further possibility of modification in electronic as well as ionic conductivity and other crucial parameters responsible for enhancing their catalytic activity [45]. The majority of transition metals as well as novel metals are widely studied as metal single atoms on different substrates like carbon [84], metal oxide [85], metal sulfide [86], etc. Usually, the interaction between metal and carbon support causes a positive charge density on the central metal atom, which leads to e−-transfer to support from the M-atom [87]. For instance, the chemical and structural stability of noble metal catalysts is greatly enhanced by metal-support interactions in atomically dispersed supported iridium (Ir) and platinum (Pt) catalysts, which usually include cations bound to oxygen, carbon, or nitrogen atoms. This sort of metal support interaction is also extensively studied in atomically precise M-N-C SACs to monitor their electronic structure which has an effect on the intrinsic catalytic activity of catalysts in different electrocatalytic reactions [88,89]. In spite of the fact that the atomically precise M-N-C SACs gained considerable compositional diversity, the MNx active sites are found to get dispersed randomly and without being controlled on the substrate, resulting deficiency in electronic synergy of active sites [90]. An efficient sub-class of these catalysts with adjacent single metal atoms having unique geometric features and improved electrocatalytic activity has been reported [91]. After considering the geographic proximity of all single metal atoms, this form of the catalyst may be represented as M-N-C DACs, and displays one more interaction, metal–metal (M-M) interaction via transfer of electrons between adjacent metal site atoms [92,93] compare to traditional M-N-C SACs. Atomically precise M-N-C catalysts are able to exhibit structural flexibility due to the fact that the local configuration and charge density of the metal center are significantly influenced by the number and type of nearby atoms in the first and subsequent coordination shells [94]. Moreover, atomically precise M-N-C DACs display different geometric structures with higher flexibility to tune electronic as well as electrocatalytic properties, unlike the supported metallic cluster/NPs. For instance, short-ordered Ir single atom integrated in Co-oxide display Ir-Ir interaction, facilitating the inflection of electronic configuration of active sites resulting in extra-ordinary performance in the OER process [95]. Moreover, di-atomic metal pairs (like Zn-Co [96], Ni-Fe [97], etc) coordinated on Co-based support are reported to have electronic properties favorable for electrocatalytic application. The metal support interaction is critically evaluated [98,99], even though both interactions have a significant role to play in single atom-based materials. The M-M interaction in M-N-C DACs is assumed to be generated from electronic perturbation, among isolated metal sites as well as high volatility of d-orbitals, and thus this interaction opens a huge opportunity for structural regulation in atomically precise M-N-C catalysts [100]. In addition to the direct influence from the neighboring metal site, the M-M interaction is influenced by type of substrate, charge density, local coordination as well as topological structure of central-atomic site. Fig. 3 shows the typical illustration of the role of M-support interaction, M-M interaction, coordination environment, and spin states on the ORR activity of atomically precise MNx catalysts, offering synergy to reduce the OO bond to achieve 4e− ORR. In order to understand the unique geometry and electronic structure of atomically precise M-N-C catalysts, the techniques like advanced electron microscopy [101,102], theoretical calculation [103], and ex-situ and in-situ spectroscopic characterization are employed to evaluate the M-support interaction, coordination environment, and M-M interaction in these catalysts, as discussed in next sub-section. 2.3 Identification of local coordination of M-N-C catalytic moieties To identify the local coordination structure, like M-M interaction, intersite distance, and M-support interaction in particular, of atomically precise M-N-C active site, many advanced electron microscopies and spectroscopies have been utilized. For instance, extended X-ray adsorption fine structure (EXAFS) region, originated from interaction of adjacent M-atoms with photoelectrons, is capable of opening the mystery of M-M bonds in atomically precise catalysts (Fig. 4 a). However, due to the uniformity in atomic structure of dispersed isolated atomic sites in these catalysts, this technique may not be suitable to differentiate the atomic sites and low nuclearity metallic clusters [104,105]. In a similar way, it is a really challenging task to detect the non-appearance of small NPs or metallic clusters (<1–2 nm) incorporated into a crystalline lattice using the XRD technique. On the basis of a distinct shift in Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra due to CO (used as probe) chemisorption on atomically dispersed M-sites compared to NPs, the investigation of existence of atomically dispersed atomic sites can be approached [106]. The obtained results strongly rely on two following factors; (i) the capability of adsorption of probe molecule by atomically dispersed metal atom (kind of M-atom), and (ii) the landscape of the host system (which can affect the probe molecule chemisorption ability of the single atom metal). Determining the inherent dispersion of single atomic sites on an object, their distinct exposure by target molecules, and the actual proportion that participates in a reaction using chemisorption approaches is thus difficult and currently beyond the range of current methods. Although this method is frequently the most effective way to discourse the confines of existing characterization protocols, it is important to proceed with extreme caution when interpreting the results, particularly in cases where the structures that were created are purely postulated. Conducting a thorough speciation examination to choose the most demonstrative contender from the pool of potential active sites is a more reliable strategy, and the local coordination of an atomically precise M-N-C active site can be found using a variety of cutting-edge electron microscopy and spectroscopy methods as well as theoretical investigations (Fig. 4b). These methods include measuring the interaction between metals, the distance between sites, and the interaction between metals and supports. Speciation studies of Pt and Au embedded in C-sheets have shown that many species can provide the equivalent XAS outcomes, suggesting that their co-existence should be taken into consideration [107,108]. The experimental investigations often fail to provide information about the local geometry of atomically precise catalysts, despite the fact that this geometry typically plays a pivotal role in determining the electronic structure and catalytic features of their active sites. For example, it is not an easy process to distinguish between the elements of coordinating atoms that occur at the same period (such as C, N, and O). Similarly, it is not an easy process to determine the precise structural properties of metal connectivity with O, OH, or OH2 species. When trying to identify the active site’s local structure during the reaction process, this task becomes more challenging. Theoretical calculations can shed light on the actual structural characterization of atomically precise catalysts by proposing their geometrical and electronic structures based on the results of spectroscopic simulations. This allows for a wealth of information to be compared with experimental measurements [62,69]. Despite the utilization of many modern techniques such as XPS and XANES, the accurate identification of the true active site and the co-existence of pyridinic-N and pyrrolic-N, as well as their significance in ORR, remain hard [82,109]. Hossain et al. [110], for example, employed the XPS technique to study the local chemical structure of a particular element by running core-level shift simulations for N 1s and C 1s for the NiNC catalysts. However, the core level shift differences for different N-atoms were found to be very tiny, which is very difficult to be determined by present spectroscopy. Identifying the coordination arrangement around the CoP moieties becomes possible when a single metal atom is coordinated with hetero-atoms at a distinct period, such as Co1 P anchored on P-doped graphitic carbon nitrides. Co is encircled by approximately four P atoms, and no P-P connection is established, according to EXAFS [111]. In the P 2p XPS spectrum, there were two clear peaks at 133.1 and 129.5 eV due to the connectivity between P and N-atoms in the C3N4 framework and to the Co site, respectively (Fig. 5 a). Nevertheless, the local structure of P(Co) remains uncertain, but potential structural details about the Co-P center could be uncovered by comparing the binding energies of P in various local environments. It might be possible to find the real structure of CoP, which is a dispersed atomic site, by using theoretical core-level shift calculations based on built structures along with stability testing. It is possible that core-level shift calculations will become more crucial in differentiating the fine structures of SACs as the experimental binding energy resolution improves. While characterizing prepared SACs is vital, understanding the true structure during reaction conditions is more crucial for catalytic performance, yet determining this structure remains a huge difficulty. The in-situ/operando characterization approaches, a relatively new development in characterization techniques, have allowed for the determination of an increasing number of structures in operational conditions. The operando XAS results showed that a highly oxidized HO-Co1-N2 adduct species was present on g-C3N4 at an open circuit (Fig. 5b) [112]. However, during HER in basic media, the main species identified was H2O-(OH-Co1-N2) at −0.4 V [112]. In a similar way, during HER in basic media, it was shown that the Ru1-N4 site anchored in g-C3N4 exists as O-Ru1-N4 [113]. Theoretical models have shown that the adsorption of exogenous species such as *OH or *O can enhance the catalytic activity by reducing the overpotential. A recent discovery was made utilizing the XPS technique. It was shown that Pt0 (non-coordinated) g-C3N4 was formed when the photocatalytic H2O splitting reaction caused the rupture of PtN bonds and the reconstruction of CN bonding [7]. Additionally, operando EXAFS’s demonstration of a dynamic near-free state of a single atom by lowering the Pt1 atom’s coordination number on an N-C matrix in a basic media. Because single-atom catalytic processes are so complicated, it can be hard to do theoretical simulations of things like building new structures or simulating reactions in excited states [114]. This is because the oxidation states of single metal atoms change during reactions. In this case, the goal of studying M-M interactions in C-SACs is to figure out the electronic structure and coordination geometry of single atomic sites. Characterizing individual metal atoms using methods that concentrate on crystalline structure, like X-ray diffraction (XRD), can be challenging due to the absence of long-range order at the metal sites. The geometric properties of these materials may now be directly observed and structurally identified thanks to developments in electron microscopic characterization techniques [115]. In addition to directly examining the atomic structure of SACs-based materials, one can find additional proof of M-M interactions between metal atoms by looking at their local coordination environment. The extensive use of X-ray absorption spectroscopy, a highly effective method, can directly reveal the local structure of target atoms. Simultaneously, by examining the chemical adsorption and disintegration behavior of target atoms using various probing molecules of gases, FT-IR and temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) spectroscopies can provide indirect information about M-M communication. Surface-sensitive XPS techniques can be used to learn more about the chemical states of atoms that are linked together. One way to show how M-atoms coordinate and transfer charges is by adjusting the move and percentage of deconvoluted XPS peaks [116]. Electron transition energy measurements, obtained by XANES, have been found extensively applicable to investigate the average chemical state of metallic sites. This energy is significant for the assessment of interactions between individual M-atoms and their neighboring atoms. Surfaced M-atoms are typically coordinated with non-metal atoms of the substrate and their edges, and they are close to reference M-oxide and foil. Correlated M-sites frequently have slightly different valence states than single atoms in isolation due to the modified electronic transition comportment generated by M-M communication [116]. The pre-edge peak, for example, can reveal the hybridization between 3d and 4p orbitals of Ni in a Ni/Fe-N-C having dual-atomic site arrangements of Ni and Fe. Ni/Fe-N-C had a higher pre-peak intensity than Ni-N-C and Ni-Pc. This meant that the Ni species in this compound had changed its D4h symmetry because of M-M coordination [117]. EXAFS measurements are also often used to get a better idea of the bond distance and coordination number of target atoms in their immediate coordination environment. The typical FT-EXAFS spectra of normal SACs demonstrate that the majority of coordination takes place at the first shell, and there is no second-shell M-M pathway. The SACs-based materials, on the other hand, display the good characteristics of both coordination types due to the presence of M-support and M-M contacts simultaneously. Analysing M-M interactions between correlated single atoms can be accomplished by fitting the experimental FT-EXAFS spectra, which can yield information on local coordination, such as the atomic distance and coordination number of the M-M dispersion channel. Additionally, the unique M-M coordination structure of SACs-based materials can be found by comparing the experimental spectra to the simulated XANES spectra [116]. For instance, a Fe-Co dual-atom catalyst’s Fe K-edge FT-EXAFS spectrum showed two peaks at 1.51 Å and 2.25 Å, which can be attributed to the first-shell Fe-N coordination and Fe-Co coordination, respectively [118]. Theoretical simulations utilizing N-coordinated dual atomic arrangements of Fe and Co embedded in a C-matric produced simulated Fe K-edge spectra that are consistent with Fe-Co coordination. However, the fact that catalyst FT-EXAFS spectra do not show an M-M channel suggests that Fe or Co single atoms are spread out on their own. Unlike M-N-C structures with a solitary M-site in porphyrin molecules, the M-M link of dual-atomic sites deforms local coordination and changes the electronic structure. There are strong oxygen-binding sites on the Fe-Co dual-site catalyst, which makes it possible to activate O2 and easily break the OO bond. Furthermore, a more direct illustration of the M-M interactions among SA metal can be provided by the wavelet transform (WT)-EXAFS investigations. For instance, the Mo K-edge WT-EXAFS outcomes were associated with the standardized references in order to ascertain the M-M communication in dual-atomic W1Mo1-NG and Mo2-NG catalysts. Fig. 5c shows that neither W1Mo1-NG nor Mo2-NG shows the WT responses related to direct Mo-Mo interaction in Mo foil [119]. But when the signals’ intensity for the W1Mo1-NG and Mo2-NG catalysts were compared with MoO3, the MoO and MoOW/Mo bonding were observed, respectively. This provides strong evidence for the Mo-W and Mo-hetero-atom interactions. Furthermore, unlike the FT-EXAFS fitting responses, which evaluate the coordination arrangement by isolating the near atoms based on their distances from the central metal site, the WT-EXAFS can identify the single atomic sites inside the coordination shell with the aid of vertebral trickle wave functions in energy interplanetary. For multi-atomic shells, such as the 2nd coordination sphere M-site on metallic substrates, the investigation using the WT-EXAFS technique is a better choice. For instance, in an Ir0.06Co2.94O4 catalyst, the Ir site displays a 2nd coordination sphere that is derived from both cobalt and iridium. Ir single atoms that are linked together are added to the lattice Co oxide spinel to make this coordination happen. The results of this characterization clearly identify the 2nd coordination region as having the existence of Ir-Co and Ir-Ir atomic arrangements. However, as shown by DFT as well as experimental investigations, the associated noble metallic moieties can be differentiated from isolated single metal sites on the basis of different CO chemisorption patterns [113,120]. In this context, the interaction between correlated M-active sites might impact CO chemisorption and the properties of the central M-site, which makes CO-DRIFTS a viable choice to study the local coordination geometry of the main active sites in SACs. As an example, in-situ CO-DRIFTS chemisorption measurements in Ni1Cu2/g-C3N4 catalysts with one Ni atom restricted by two Cu atoms to Ni1/g-C3N4 and Cu1/g-C3N4 with one kind of metal site can confirm the direct connection between Cu and Ni. According to Fig. 5d of Cu1/g-C3N4, the CO chemisorption peak was observed at 2103 and 2123 cm−1 on isolated Cu+ and trimers, but Ni1/g-C3N4 showed almost no CO chemisorption [121]. The direct interaction between Cu and Ni results in a marked decrease in CO chemisorption on Cu sites, as is confirmed by the fact that the CO peak strength decreases as Ni is deposited on Cu1/g-C3N4. The adsorption and desorption behavior of different gas molecules can be evaluated using TPD measurements, which, like DRIFTS, can show the interaction among correlated single atoms. As an example, Li et al. [122] examined the behavior of H2 desorption on Pt/MoS2 catalysts with different Pt levels using H2-TPD (Fig. 5e). The hydrogen desorption temperature (H2 desorption) of Pt/MoS2 catalysts containing mostly isolated Pt atoms is approximately 311.2 °C; however, it can be significantly reduced to 283.5 °C by increasing the Pt content to create covalently bound Pt sites. This finding suggests that the Pt sites connected to it have better hydrogen dissociation through synergistic interaction. This lets the catalytic properties for CO2 hydrogenation be changed. Also, when comparing the O2-TPD profile of pure MnO2 with that of neighboring Fe SAC that was hosted by MnO2, an extra distinctive peak at 192 °C was seen [123]. This suggests that more oxygen species are being formed on the Fe sites that are connected, which makes O2 activation stronger and CO oxidation more efficient. Overall, even though atomically dispersed M-N-C nanoscale structures are easier to understand than those of similar materials, it is still very hard to find the main active site that has its own unique geometrical and electronic states. To gain an understanding of active centers, both in-situ and ex-situ characterizations require advanced methods. These observations and discoveries greatly impact our current understanding of how site density at isolated single-atom sites promotes electrocatalytic activity. Characterization methods and benchmark evaluations of these catalysts necessitate the use of advanced techniques. 3 Advanced tailoring approaches for active sites for ORR As a single atom should not be considered as a way of size reduction of NPs, likewise the reaction protocol along with the mechanism involved in atomically precise catalysts can not be treated just as a repetition process taking place on catalysts at the nanoscale. Atomically precise catalysts offer an effective base to explore new catalytic mechanisms connecting closely both homogeneous with heterogeneous catalysis. Atomically precise catalysts with highly efficient coordination enable the adsorption of numerous reacting substances and/or intermediates. These catalysts have the ability to synergistically interact with their surrounding environment without any restrictions. In addition, the precise atomic structure and electrical properties of these catalysts, particularly under real reaction conditions, have the possibility of creating novel reaction pathways with lower energy barriers than what researchers can now conceive. Furthermore, the examination of the reaction’s kinetics may provide an additional perspective on comprehending the fundamental mechanism of atomically precise catalysts. The subsequent sub-sections provide a comprehensive analysis of the tailoring methods, which encompass inter-site distance, M-M interaction, and coordinating environment, with a focus on intricate details. 3.1 Inter-site distance Usually, DACs having direct M-M communication (like M1-M2-N6) and indirect M-M contact (like M-N4/M-N4) have been prepared to catalyze the Fenton-like processes. Recently, the advanced preparation approaches for such electrocatalysts have been well engaged with the aim of improving the mass loading of active sites with the above-mentioned features [124]. The impact of mass loading on active sites has been noted to have a considerable effect on the distance between neighboring M-sites. This makes the design of diatomic sites both interesting and critical in the electrocatalysis of small molecules. Since the rupture of OO bonding and the desorption of OH* species are crucial steps in electrocatalytic ORR and Fenton-like processes, studying ORR with these catalysts can serve as a reference. For instance, Jin et al. [125] investigated the impact of Fe inter-atomic distance on the ORR activity of Fe-N-C material [126]. The XANES and Mossbaur studies suggested that inter-site distance can induce valance changes along with distortion in the D4h symmetry of Fe-N4-C catalytic moieties and be able to change the spin states. On the basis of these findings, D1 sites were attributed to LS Fe(II)-N4 or HS Fe(III)-N4, with 56% and 63% having 1.9 and 0.5 nm Fe inter-site distances, respectively. The spin moment was observed to decrease with the lower inter-site distance of 1.6 nm and caused a higher degree of eg electron’s filling, thereby improving the desorption of OH*, as verified by the DFT simulations. The experimental results demonstrated enhanced performance while distancing reduction from 1.2 to 0.7 nm (optimum) (Fig. 6 (a–c)), below which a slight fall in the intrinsic activity was recorded which might be due to optimized ΔGOH*. When the distance between Fe atoms got smaller, the XANES measurement showed that the valence state went down and the distortion in the basal plane D4h symmetry went up. This led to improved electronic activity and enhanced overall ORR performance of the FeNx-C catalyst, as shown in Fig. 6d. Mossbauer spectroscopy demonstrated that alterations in the spin states, resulting from fluctuations in the interatomic distance due to variation in dz 2 orbital filling, affected ORR activity (Fig. 6e). Similar mechanism can be expected to get developed towards the magnetic moment, essential for overlapping of metal dz 2 and pz orbital of O-adsorbates. When two Fe-atoms come closure favors higher orbital filling for eg electrons via downshifting of energy of dz 2 orbital leads to reduced spin moment. Consequently, the increased occupation of partially filled d-orbitals weakens the strength of the MOH bond. It is possible to determine the relationship between ΔGOH* and inter-atomic distance by looking at variations in spin state, magnetic moment, and basal D4h symmetry (Fig. 6(f, g)). Fig. 6h shows a remarkable link between the TOF and the d-site, which is based on the fact that normalization of kinetic current is made due to the number of Fe active sites. There are slight variations among samples with smaller Fe loadings, and the TOF variation starts at a d-site of approximately 1.2 nm. Furthermore, TOF reaches a peak at 0.7 nm, suggesting that individual sites have similar or slightly lower intrinsic performance, even when there is further proximity among nearby Fe atoms. The rate constant (k′) for oxygen binding to Fe(ii)-N4 with varied d-site values is shown in Fig. 6i. This rate constant is critical for ORR on the surface with the highest activity. The plot shows an increase in k′ at d-sites of 1.2 and 0.7 nm, which is similar to the increase in O-activation activity shown in TOF Fig. 6h. On the other hand, the mutual atomic distance in DAC structures can affect various valance states, basal D4h symmetry, dz 2 occupancy, magnetic moment, and spin states, which in turn can affect Fenton-like performance. Therefore, the steps stated below should be adopted to monitor the inter-site distance: (i) varying the metal precursor’s concentration; (ii) varying the active site density; and (ii) performing acid etching to discard unused metallic moieties or NPs. Regulation of site density of SACs ensures improvement of electrocatalytic performance like ORR. However, who governs the catalytic nature, individual and interacting site is indefinable and needs to be understood. So, in this review, we attempted to highlight the basis of the increment of ORR performance of FeN4 SACs over inter-site distances down to the sub-nanometer level. The electronic structure gets altered due to strong interaction between adjacent FeN4 moieties when inter-site distance is less than about 1.2 nm, and thus intrinsic ORR performance gets enhanced. Significant improvement in site performance goes on till nearby Fe atoms are as close as 0.7 nm, below which a slight decrement in intrinsic activity is viewed. Such type investigations highlight the importance of identification of fundamental mechanism involved in the inter-site distance effect in FeN4 catalyst for ORR which may promote the complete potential of density population in SACs. On the other hand, the kinetic behavior of isolated active sites as well as proximity effects of the neighboring metal atom can be determined which helps advance the understanding of the inherent behavior of atomically precise M-N-C catalysts. However, the concern of interaction between neighboring atoms gets increased simultaneously with site proximity on the substrate. Although a lot of studies are made on this topic, very little experimental work is reported towards developing a relationship of inter-site distance (d-site) with the catalysts at the individual site [37,122,127]. ORR being a multi-phase process with a difficult mechanism, quantification of this effect is difficult owing to the limitation of available techniques. In order to propose a methodical analysis of the d-site effect in FeN4 SACs for ORR, Han et al. [128] reported the impact of active site density on catalytic reaction suggesting it to be crucial to unearth the understanding of how single atom catalysts work. The neighboring effect between two adjacent Fe-N-C sites of mono-dispersed Fe-N-C catalyst on ORR (Fig. 7 (a–c)). Assigning FeR as a variable and FeL of FeN3 (II/III) as a reaction site allows one to begin comparing different models. The O2-adduct charge densities for all models are shown in Fig. 7(d–f). The FeN3(II/III) models’ ORR-free energy diagram is shown in Fig. 7g. It is thought that the 4e-ORR pathways on FeN3(I) will start with O2 attaching to Fe-atoms through an associative process after reductive hydrogenation. The strong link between the OO bond length of 1.42 Å and the O2 gets bonded in a site-on configuration with an adsorption energy of −2.66 eV, which is explained by the strong hybridization between the Op and Fed orbitals (Fig. 7h). This exothermic process (−1.77 eV) produces the *OOH through an H+-linked reduction phase [129]. In order to make ORR on FeN3(I) energetically unfavorable, 1.07 eV energy inputs are required at this phase. The quantity of charge transfer from both FeN3 and adsorbed O2 is greatly impacted by the intersite distance if the adjacent FeN3 site is vacant. There is less O2 adsorption, more O2 charge (0.85 → 0.91 e−), and the OO bond length is getting longer (1.417 → 1.435 Å). This is because two FeN3 sites are getting closer to each other (19.8 → 7.1 Å). Structure modification, charge transfer, and adsorption enhancement of a similar kind are observed during *OH adsorption. When the Fe-Fe distance gets bigger, the Fe-O ionic connection between *O2 and Fe gets stronger. This is why the binding strengths of *O2 and *OH get stronger (Fig. 7(k–l)). The d-band centre of the active site was used to assess the adsorption strength of the built models [130]. By acting as an electron-withdrawing group, the pre-adsorbed O2/OH on FeR might cause a downshift of the d-band centre of the neighbouring FeL (Fig. 7n). This, in turn, facilitates the last phase of ORR gest by lowering the free energy of intermediate adsorption. While this is happening, the intersite distance decreases because various pre-adsorbed species at nearby sites move the d-band centers of empty FeN3 sites [131]. Usually, UL depends on inter-site distance along with the nature of adjacent active sites in FeN3 and nearly 4 Å apart between two FeN4 sites is essential. However, such investigation also indicated unfavorable physiosorbed-O2-initiated 2e− ORR due to charge transfer between active sites and graphene-like support under certain conditions. Therefore, more innovative SAC designs with a high density of catalytic active sites and the hope of a 4e− ORR mechanism are to be yielded. Recently, Zuo et al. [132] have synthesized a chain of new pyridyl-conjugated microporous polymers being utilized as polymeric precursors to make carbonaceous materials for ORR (Fig. 8 (a–d)). FeN4C single atom with Fe–Fe bond with nearly 0.23 nm distance was reported by an experimental study showing significant ORR performance in the form of high E 1/2 as well as extended stability (Fig. 8(e, f)). A thorough comprehension of the variations in ORR activity across several FeN4-based catalysts was achieved through the use of theoretical calculations, considering one FeN4 site and two FeN4 sites with 0.75, 0.5, and 0.23 nm distances (Fig. 8(g–j)). The combined results of the structural study of the synthesized FeN4 C4 and FeFe bond are 2.15 Å, which is the same as the Fe-Fe-0.23 nm. Fig. 8k shows the Fe-Fe-0.23 reaction process and the ORR free energy diagram. All of the catalysts’ intermediates had much stronger binding energies to FeN4, Fe-Fe-0.75 nm, and Fe-Fe-0.51 nm, compared to Fe-Fe-0.23, which had weaker binding energies to these intermediates (Fig. 8l). This made the whole reaction more active. On catalysts with sizes of 0.23 nm for FeN4, 0.26 nm for Fe-Fe-0.75 nm, and 0.38 eV for Fe-Fe-0.51 nm, the last step (*OH + 3OH− + e− → 4OH− + *) is endothermic, indicating that there is an excessively strong interaction with the *OH intermediate, which makes it impossible to create OH−. Fig. 8m displays that Fe-Fe-0.23 nm is the best catalyst for the ORR process because it has steps that are better from a thermodynamic point of view. Fig. 8n shows that the free energy decreases as the d-site decreases, then increases until a mutation occurs at d-site = 0.23 nm, and finally drops to its minimal value. According to reports, strong interaction between adjacent FeN4 sites changes the electronic structure when the distance between them is less than 1.2 nm. This leads to improved intrinsic ORR performance, which continues to improve until the Fe adjustment reaches approximately 0.7 nm, after which there is a slight decrease in intrinsic activity [125,133]. The FeN4C-based catalysts, highly dependent on the density and distance of the FeN4 active center display remarkable ORR performance and Zn-air batteries. Thus, this work offers a way to design cost-effective SACs having high intrinsic activity as well as active site density for energy conservation systems. 3.2 Metal-support and metal–metal interactions In most cases, O2 binds to an active site with a side-on or end-on adsorption configuration. When there is more than one active site, however, O2 adsorption favors the formation of cis-bridge O2 adducts on the active site. These adducts let the O-atoms on each site coordinate with each other, which leads to the 4e− ORR [134]. Particularly in this case of atomically precise M-N-C materials, the creation of M-M sites in the fashion of dual- or multi-active sites in close proximity can be highly beneficial, offering direct OO bond rupture [118], and thereby demonstrating outstanding ORR. Due to their inherent compositional and structural manipulation versatility, N-C frameworks offer an excellent platform for attaching dual- or multi-active sites at suitable distances while also allowing a high degree of control of mettalic sites with remarkable density. Therefore, a careful design and proper local arrangement modulation of atomically precise catalysts is essential for M-support, and M-M interaction understanding and their implementation in electrocatalysis. In order to accommodate such achievements, a few protocols offering the incorporation of support and additional metallic centers in close proximity to the main active site are reported. Fig. 9 a illustrates a common electrical connection between a metal and its local coordination, which serves as a support for accommodating a single metal atom in atomically precise M-N-C catalysts. The presence of N-atoms in 1st coordination shell enhances the stability of the central metal atom through electron transfer. The active site’s electrocatalytic activity depends on whether it can accept or donate electrons. This depends on the electronegativity of the donor atoms and the way electrons are distributed in the environment. Typically, the interaction between metal and support facilitates the interaction between the central active site and O2 molecules when they are adsorbed on the active sites. This interaction modifies the binding energy of ORR intermediates, thereby affecting the overall ORR activity. For example, in the electrocatalytic reduction process, the presence of electron-withdrawing groups on MN4-molecular catalysts decreases the electron density on the central metal atom. This makes it easier for the atom to accept electrons from the electrode or O2 molecule at a lower potential, resulting in a reduction in the overall overpotential of the reaction [8]. The electron-withdrawing properties of the carbon matrix around the M-N-C active site in M-N-C SAC cause a change in the binding of O2 to the active site, resulting in an improvement in the ORR activity, as depicted in Fig. 9b. Hence, the interaction between the metal and the support is crucial in determining the overall ORR activity of atomically precise M-N-C catalysts. As far as metal–metal interaction is concerned, the inter-site distance between atomically dispersed metal sites in M-N-C materials is considered as a descriptor to evaluate the quantitative electronic structure, as discussed in the above sub-section. A direct strategy to monitor M-M interaction in SACs via tuning the d-site distance and regulating the site density in the lattice substrate [71,115] is demonstrated. Fig. 9c shows the typical modification of the local environment of a single metal site, via introducing another metal atom. The insertion of the second metal atom in the surrounding of the first metal atom can be made either by putting the second metal in the first shell to have direct M-M interaction or by putting it in 2nd shell to have metal-X-metal interaction (where X is the bridging ligand), offering indirect M-M interaction. Usually, the direct M-M arrangement offers a unique approach to fabricating a number of homo- and hetero-dual atomic catalysts for ORR. The M-M interaction can be assessed based on the local coordination and the charge redistribution caused by bonding with non-metal atomic sites, as well as variations in coordination configuration, as depicted in Fig. 9d. During the adsorption of O2 molecules on the directly attached M-M sites (dual-atom sites), O2 molecules can have mutual coordination with both M-sites, offering a cis-bridged O2 adduct favorable for the direct rupture of OO bonding, leading to 4e− ORR. However, the close proximity of M-M sites (dint) is crucial to offer the synergistic modification of the electronic structure of both the metal site (Fig. 9e) for breaking the scaling relationship of ORR and avoiding the formation of peroxo-adduct (2e− ORR). On the other hand, the indirect M-M interaction (M-X-M) offers the synergistic modulation of electronic features of the main catalytic active site, altering the binding energy of ORR intermediates and thus offering the probability of breaking the linear scaling relationship of ORR. The tuning of the electronic features of both metal sites depends on the electronegativity and atomic radii of the bridged ligand (X). Getting a high density of single atoms, stable in nature, is difficult due to the more mobile nature of atomically dispersed metal species at the time of synthesis [5]. Although inter-site M-M interaction is present, the amusing assortment of active sites in supported metallic nanoclusters, particularly in geometric as well as electronic structures, makes studying interaction very difficult [115]. Moreover, due to poor lattice binding of metallic sites, nanoclusters cannot be termed a single atomic entity, therefore being left out of their discussion in this review. In traditional SACs, the limited amount of metal atoms leads to arrangements where the individual sites are widely separated from each other, resulting in a lack of a d-site combined effect. Usually, the generation of unique local configurations that may be fine-tuned by adjusting the spacing between sites and the interactions between metal atoms is typically enabled by a higher concentration of individual active sites on the substrate. A recent study [91] found that by increasing the Pd loading in the SiC lattice to a maximum of 5.6%, it is possible to create contiguous Pd sites with synergistic electronic communication. The adjacent Pd atoms displayed collaborative interactions to decrease the energy of crucial reaction stages, leading to significantly enhanced catalytic efficiency compared to the isolated Pd single-atom counterparts. A crucial aspect of this approach is to limit the quantity of individual M-atoms that may be incorporated into the specific lattice of the substrate. Concentrations below the threshold result in the complete isolation of metallic sites, whilst concentrations over the threshold lead to the production of nanoclusters or NPs outdoor the substrate’s matrix. The previous study described a method called “ion-exchange-pyrolysis” that allows for the incorporation of Ir single atoms with a short-range order into the Co coordination sphere of the spinal lattice of Co oxide [95]. The created hybrid materials of IrCo3-nO4 demonstrated both M-support and M-M bondings, enabling the modification of the electronic characteristics of the active site. This is in contrast to the atomically dispersed SAC with equivalent properties. The creation of highly concentrated individual metallic sites often involves utilizing the methods used in the production of traditional SACs and is typically combined with a wet chemical methodology. Hence, it serves as an advantageous and universal approach for studying metal–metal interactions due to its straightforwardness and broad scope. Nevertheless, significant technical challenges arise from the complexity of accurately managing the local coordination and formation of heteronuclear inter-site interactions. Furthermore, it is crucial to thoroughly investigate the selection of the substrate and the related threshold of metal single atoms that can be integrated into the given substrate [115]. The interaction between individual M-atoms and substrates can alter the catalytic performance in a variety of ways, such as through changes to the electronic structure and spatial coordination. Each time a single atom interacts with substrates, it either turns on central M-sites, central M-atoms along with adjacent bonded atoms, or just the bonded atoms. These activated sites are responsible for catalytic processes. Therefore, a thorough examination of the active sites is imperative. Moreover, the ever-changing development of geometric or electrical structures offers fresh insights into reactions on SACs [135]. 3.3 Coordination environment Material scientists are interested in improving the performance of atomically precise M-N-C catalysts by tailoring the coordination environment of single atoms. Usually, when an individual M-atom interacts with an N-heteroatom or another bonded M-atom that is embedded in a graphitized C-matrix, it produces features that are similar to those of molecular ligands in terms of geometry and electronics. One important thing that affects the M-N-C material’s stability as well as activity is the valence state of the core M-atom. This state mainly controls the flexible coordination environment around each atom. Scientists can also control the unusual charge transfer and anchor the single atoms by binding them through ionic or covalent contacts by moving the atoms around them. This makes it possible to design the 2nd coordination shell and beyond. In spite of this, even relatively insignificant materials can have a significant impact on the adsorption phenomena, which in turn can affect the catalysis in some way [137–140]. Typically, changing the coordinating environment can adjust the geometric structure of the active site and affect the electronic configuration (Fig. 10 a), resulting in a shift in the d-band center. These facts modify the adsorption energy of the reaction intermediates, hence increasing the electrocatalytic activity of the active site. For example, Hunter et al. [141] introduced a set of catalyst models based on CoPt@NxVy, where x represents the nitrogen coordination and y represents the carbon coordination. The results of this study showed that by raising the N-coordination number, the CoPt@NxCy models can exhibit improved HER catalytic activity. Motivated by these ideas, Zhao et al. [142] performed a comprehensive theoretical calculation on graphene-supported bi-metal atoms and single-metal atoms modified with hydroxyl groups to examine the electrocatalytic ORR and OER variation in an alkaline medium. A higher coordination number of the central metal atom with the help of a hydroxyl group was found to considerably enhance the electrocatalytic activity of the built models towards ORR and OER. In a recent study, Xiao et al. [83] performed a thorough analysis of atomically dispersed catalysts using in situ Fe K-edge XANES characterization techniques. They discovered that hydroxyl groups coordinate with Fe-Co metal sites in a triangular Fe-Co-OH configuration within the FeCoN5 coordination sphere. This configuration helps to weaken the OO bonding, enabling easy breaking of the OO linkage and resulting in high ORR activity. Hence, with a moderate FeO binding energy, FeCoN5-OH rose near to the peak of the ORR volcano curve. Additionally, the unavoidable Fenton reaction between the Fe active sites and the H2O2 by-product may result in the production of hydroxyl and oxygen radicals. These radicals have the potential to impact the active sites, resulting in diminished durability. The results of the catalyst preparation process by Ye et al. are shown in Fig. 10(b–d) [135]. They used the precursor pre-selection method to make Fe1-N-C, Fe2-N-C, and Fe3-N-C electrocatalysts that could be tuned. Based on the results obtained from low-temperature FT-IR studies, they determined that the three moieties could display distinct modes of O2 adsorption: end-on adsorption for Fe1-N-C and peroxo-like adsorption for Fe2-N-C and Fe3-N-C (Fig. 10(e, f)). Additionally, the Fe clusters could tailor the N-species ingrained in the carbon matrix during pyrolysis toward increased activity and electron transport. The arrangement of O2 molecules on Fex-N-C may, in part, activate them. In more detail, the adsorbed oxygen might be more activated in the side-on mode by receiving extra electrons from the multiple active sites and donating them to its empty orbitals. With the same amount of iron, Fe2-N-C could offer more catalytic moieties than Fe3-N-C. Fe2-N-C was also more graphitized than Fe3-N-C and could supply more pyridinic N species than Fe1-N-C. Therefore, Fe2-N-C outperformed Fe3-N-C in acidic conditions, while Fe1-N-C had the worst performance. Fe2-N-C had an E 1/2 of 0.78 V. In 0.5 M H2SO4 and 0.1 M HClO4, respectively, there was a −20 mV and − 79 mV difference between RHE and the commercial Pt/C, making it the best of the three materials. After the CV 20,000 cycles, a little shift of −20 mV was noted, indicating that Fe2-N-C exhibited exceptional durability. Additional studies conducted on these catalysts in an acidic environment also hinted that Fe2-N-C could potentially function throughout a wide pH spectrum [135]. Possibly, five different coordination numbers (x = 1–5) are there for the catalytic active site that is connected to FeNx residues. The charge distribution of active sites is significantly affected by these coordination numbers, which in turn affects the catalytic efficiency of the M-N-C catalyst [143–145]. The optimization of the ORR intermediates O*, OH*, and OOH* was used in the computational investigations conducted on FeNx (x = 1–5). Because FeN4 has the minimum free energy for the rate-determining phase of ORR, it is easier to remove H2O from FeN4, which inhibits OH* adsorption. The hypothetical order of ORR activity was determined to be FeN4 > FeN3 > FeN2 > FeN1 > FeN5. Therefore, the Fe-N-C catalyst must possess a strong FeN4 active center with the 4 coordination number for the establization of the metallic part present in a host carbon matrix. Due to the fact that the host material and central metal ion determine the single-atom coordination sphere, it is possible for various single-transition metals placed on graphene or N-doped graphene to exhibit identical coordination spheres [146]. The metal atom with 3 or 4 N-donor atoms is found to be a suitable combination with Fe-N4 [147], Co-N4 [129], Zn-N4 [148], Cu-N3 [149], Zn-N3-Co-N3 [150], or Fe-N3-Co-N3 [151] and are superior in stability (Fig. 11 a(i)) [152], as revealed by both theoretical as well as experimental studies. The coordination of a single iron atom with four oxygen atoms in GO results in the formation of Fe-O4 moieties [153]. It was previously thought that in order to remove Fe ions from the bulk crystal and stop them from building up on the GO surface, four O-coordination bonds were required [153]. The coordination bonds that connect specific metal atoms have an impact on how well electrochemical ORRs perform. For instance, according to DFT calculations, the removal of OH * from the Cu-N3-C active site is the rate-determining step for ORR (Fig. 11a(ii)). On the other hand, for a single unoccupied coordination site that contains Cu-N3-C (Cu-N3-V) [149,154]. Coordination number of Cu-atom determines the ORR overpotential as demonstrated by DFT analysis and displayed 0.52 V as E onset with Cu-N3-V remarkably less than Cu-N3 (1.37 V) and Cu-N3-C (0.83 V) (Fig. 11a(iii)) [149]. The E onset was dependent on isolated Cu’s coordination number, much less compared to Cu-N3 (1.37 V) as well as Cu-N3-C (0.83 V). Because there are coordination vacancies in Cu-N3, the electrons around the Cu atoms are redistributed in a way that is not symmetrical. This is what causes the reduced overpotential with Cu-N3-V. A lower positive charge on an isolated Fe-atom was seen in this study compared to N-doped and N and P co-doped HC (Fig. 11a(iv)), suggesting that Fe atoms draw more electrons from nearby S and P atoms [155,159]. Further, to enhance catalyst performance, one effective technique is to modify the electronic structure surrounding the metal active site. By changing the electrical environment around the active site, Han et al. [156] first described the FeCl1N4/CNS catalyst that was spread out atomically (Fig. 11b(i–iii)) and had much better ORR activity. The coordinated chloride ion gave the FeCl1N4/CNS a different E 1/2 value than FeN4/CN and Pt/C (Fig. 11b(iv)). Fig. 11b(v) shows that it was very stable, had a decent resistance to methanol, and had an extremely high J k of 41.11 mA/cm2 at 0.85 V. In addition, DFT studies indicated the possibility of optimization due to short-range contact with atomic chlorine as well as long-range contact with S-atom. This resulted in a notable enhancement in ORR performance in basic media (Fig. 11b(vi–vii)). This research threw open a lot of new opportunities for developing high-tech electrocatalysts. Using DFT computations, another study examined three atomically distributed FeN4 moieties with varied carbon matrixes: FeN4-C8, FeN4-C10, and FeN4-C12. The activation energy required to break the OO bond using the 4e-ORR route was lowest at FeN4 sites because there were fewer nearby C-atoms (FeN4-C8 at the micropore edge) [143,160–162]. That is why the Fe-NC catalyst with micropores could make the best local C-structure (Fig. 11c(i)) [143]. Afterward, it enhanced intrinsic activity by producing additional FeN4-C8 active sites. According to experimental evidence, the Mössbauer and XANES spectra of FeN4 further associate the local C-structure with internal activity [163,164]. Mossbauer spectroscopy stands out as the gold standard for differentiating FeN4 species with varying local C-structures [165]. Recently, Mössbauer spectroscopy was used to study two types of FeN4 active sites, FeN4-C8 and FeN4-C10. The D1 was assigned to the FeN2+2 configuration and the D2 to the in-plane FeN4 configuration (Fig. 11c(ii)). The outstanding ORR properties were discovered to be caused by the FeN4C8 (D1) active sites [157]. 3.4 Spin state of central atom For improving the ORR performance of atomically precise M-N-C catalysts, the aforementioned important approaches, which include metal-support and metal–metal contacts, inter-site distance, and coordination environment, have been studied extensively and are moderate. Despite the fact that these catalysts are supposedly the best alternative to Pt-based catalysts, the suggested mechanism for improving the catalytic property of the ligand field of single-atom metal N-C sites remains ambiguous. Recent investigations have shown that the movement of 3d electrons of Fe can cause changes in the electron spin state, which in turn affects the ORR activity. This phenomenon appears to be relevant to the valence state and chemical environment of the Fe core [166–168]. In order to hypothesize this concept, Xue et al. [169] developed three distinct types of Fe-N-C-based electrocatalysts having different N-coordination numbers (FeN5, FeN4, and FeN3) via a self-assembled template-assisted pyrolysis protocol, aiming to evaluate the basis of ORR activity in Fe-Nx catalysts via electronic modulation as well as chemical configuration transformation in particular. The EXAFS and magnetic investigations established the correlation of the coordination number with the electron spin state of the central active site. High spin (HS) state conversion from the low spin (LS) state of the Fe-active center, specifically FeN5 (Fe-N5-LS) to FeN4 (Fe-N4-HS) and FeN3 (Fe-N3-HS), was achieved by modulating the e− spin of Fe through the transformation of the pyrollic N-coordinated FeNx site. The synergistic level, d-band center, of FeN5-LS and Fe-N5-HS was significantly higher and lower, respectively, than that of FeN4-HS, as indicated by the results of DFT (Fig. 12 (a, b). According to the “d-band” and “Sabatier’ principles” [170], the d-band center will possess an ideal adsorption aptitude for O-species in the active center, hence boosting the ORR. The electrochemical studies revealed that the Fe-N4-HS catalyst exhibited an exceptional ORR in both the acidic as well as basic environments, compared to other configurational catalysts, as shown in Fig. 12(c–f). The Fe-N4-HS displays a 3d electronic structure of t2g 3eg 2 to accelerate ORR activity significantly. The newly designed Fe-N4-HS catalyst demonstrates outstanding ORR performance similar to Pt/C catalyst. Furthermore, the engineered catalyst demonstrates better performance in PEMFC and ZABs compared to most non-precious metallic catalysts. The observation provides valuable insights into the relationship between electronic spin states and geometric structure, as well as an effective and precisely engineered Fe-N-C catalyst for ORR.
