This suggests that the activity of the catalyst is dependent on its coordination and electron spin interactions, providing a basis for designing Fe-N-C materials that are not reliant on precious metals. Nevertheless, the density of FeNx sites can have a minor impact on the activity of the ORR due to the comparable nature of the electronic communication between active sites and intermediates. Therefore, to have far more ORR activity of the FeN4 site, introducing hetero-atoms into the coordinating environment can induce distinct magnetic interactions between the active sites, thereby influencing their ORR activity. The hetero-atom-doped, atomically distributed Fe-N-C catalyst has been found to have exceptional ORR activity. However, there are differing opinions regarding the underlying reasons for this improved activity. Chen et al. [171] reported the S-doped Fe1-NC catalyst as a model with far advanced ORR activity toward conventional Fe-N-C material. Induction of transition of spin polarization due to the introduction of S-atom in the second coordination sphere of Fe-N-C was observed via mossbaur spectroscopy and ESR spectroscopy along with identification of LS single Fe3+ of C-Fe-N4-S as ORR active site. The theoretical calculation revealed the LS state of the Fe center due to S-doping to promote the OH* desorption process Fig. 12g. This work highlights the mechanism involved in S-doping to enhance ORR activity and open a new area to study broader hetero-atomic doped Fe-N-C catalysts for efficient ORR catalysis. In addition, Liu et al. [172] showed an approach to enhance the ORR performance of the iron (Fe) center by modulating the environment of the Fe-site through axial coordination of FeO ligands, which regulates the spin state transition. The FeOTi ligands in FeN3OOTi cause a transition from an LS to a medium spin state, which enhances the adsorption of oxygen by FeN3 O (Fig. 13 a). In order to demonstrate this, a focused electrocatalyst was created using an atomic iron-doped polymer, such as a quantum dot, and an extremely thin Mxene material terminated with oxygen. The catalyst exhibited an inherent activity that was nearly five times greater than the controlled system. This catalyst has demonstrated exceptional performance in both ZABs and H2/O2 FCs throughout a broad temperature range. Following a similar approach to the active site’s environment, He et al. [173] demonstrated Fe-N co-doped carbon (Fe-N-C) nanocomposite FeNxCy and the result from the first principle calculation displays a linear correlation of energy barrier or principal reaction step with Fe magnetic moment. In the experimental investigation, on the incorporation of the Cu site into Fe-N-C aerogels (as NCAG/Fe-Cu), the Fe center shows a decreased magnetic moment along with significantly improved ORR in a large pH range of 0–14. When NCAG/Fe-Cu nanocomposite was used as cathode catalyst in a neutral/quasi-solid solid Zn-air battery, achieved significant performance with an ultra-high open circuit voltage of 2 and 1.5 V, 130 and 186 mW cm−2 power density along with good mechanical flexibility far better than commercial Pt/C, Pt/C-RuO2 cathode catalysts (Fig. 13b). Overall, to improve the ORR performance of the M-N-C electrocatalyst, researchers experimented with changing the core M-spin state, MNx-C coordination geometry, site distance, and site-support interaction. M-N-C engineering tried to improve the natural properties of MNx moieties by introducing defects, hetero-atom dopants, and bi- or multi-metals into the central M-atom coordination spheres. Furthermore, it aims to improve M-support electrical communication by introducing defects or hetero-atom dopants to stabilize M-sites. However, understanding and accomplishing this level of engineering remains difficult, although better characterization techniques can help. 4 Activity descriptors for atomically precise M-N-C catalysts Electrocatalytic reactions usually consist of several phases involving the transfer of electrons and protons. These steps help the adsorbed species interact with the surfaces of the catalyst, resulting in different intensities of binding to the active sites. Consequently, this can lead to intricate reaction paths and the creation of many chemicals. Searching for the optimal catalysts can be a laborious and time-consuming task, but it is essential for controlling the production of desired products along a particular reaction route with high efficiency. Hence, it is advantageous to determine key attributes that can streamline the categorization of reactions and guide a logical approach to designing catalysts, employing techniques such as DFT simulations and the newly established improved characterization methods [30,174]. The properties outlined in the preceding section can be valuable in formulating a catalyst design plan by elucidating activity trends and identifying the most promising catalysts. 4.1 Traditional descriptors Up till now, one traditional example of a descriptor that has been used successfully for the above-mentioned purpose is the ΔGO*-ΔGOH* descriptor, which reveals the activity trend of the ORR process by utilizing the binding energies of adsorbed species *O and *OH [38]. However, the intrinsic catalyst variables that govern the strength of ORR intermediates’ attachment to the catalyst’s surface remain highly uncertain. As a result, it is difficult to use this descriptor as a general guideline for predicting new catalyst series. Consequently, in order to develop a superior global description able to aid in adjusting the adsorption nature of adsorbates, which impacts activity, it is essential to estimate the actual intrinsic properties of the catalysts. With the help of the d-band center [175,176], p-band centers [177], eg occupancy [178,179], surface distortion [180], coordinated unsaturated metal cation [181], electronegativity [29], etc., electrocatalysts have made some headway [182]. These descriptors, derived from high-level computations, often describe the activity trend of various catalysts. However, the potential drawback is that the descriptors may only be applicable to a limited set of electrocatalytic reactions. Furthermore, because these activity descriptors are based on the ionic model, they fail to adequately represent the co-valency of the M-O bonding, limiting the precise measurement of the adsorption energy of intermediates (*OH, *O, and *OOH) on the catalyst’s surface [183]. Another challenge is the poor sensitivity and complexity of identifying surface, subsurface, and bulk electronic features using these descriptors [183]. During the trial with the aim of maximization of catalytic performance, it might not be immediately obvious of getting the way for the adjustment of adsorption-free energies to their optimal ranges. In their ground-breaking work, Zeng et al. et al. [29] designed and implemented the concept of descriptors. A general description for consideration of the local environment of the metal center was proposed for different electrochemical processes with atomically precise M-N-C catalysts. Here, consideration of electronegativity, coordination number along with electron negativity of nearest neighbor are made. This general characteristic can be related to the activity of various electrochemical reactions because it is able to display linear relationships with the adsorption energies of different intermediates. Even more intriguing than the computed adsorption-free energies is the fact that all of the parameters used in the descriptor are either simply adjustable by intuition or may be tabulated directly without complex computations. In order to build and screen atomically precise catalysts with excellent performance, this descriptor and the notion behind its construction will play a more straightforward function. Thus, crucial parameters like atomic radius, coordination numbers, configurations, valence electron count, electronegativity, coordination numbers, and possibly atomic orbitals can be used to fit activity or selectivity-related descriptors [73,179,184,185]. Therefore, the design of M-N-C catalysts could benefit greatly from a description that is both easy to understand and use. And, it is anticipated that theoretical design will have a significant role to play before experimentation on M-N-C catalysts as new simulation methods, advanced machine learning strategies, and more appropriate parameters suitable for assessment of catalytic performance during practical work are developed and implemented [137,186,187]. Overall, despite the significant advancements made by descriptor-based techniques, it is important to note that each descriptor does have its limitations [188]. As a result, future M-N-C electrocatalyst designs will benefit from a more complete picture of the underlying physics and chemistry when these characteristics are correlated with one another. Moreover, none of these descriptors show the potential to serve as a uniform indicator for revealing the inherent characteristics of various catalysts. Hence, it is imperative to construct precise descriptors for the purpose of finely tuning the adsorption energies of intermediates and the overall activity of M-N-C catalysts [189,190]. Nevertheless, since these descriptors can aid in establishing a connection between the inherent characteristics of catalysts and their activity and selectivity within a range of catalysts, it is imperative to employ more precise and universally applicable descriptors to facilitate the experimental screening of optimized M-N-C catalysts. 4.2 New descriptor As discussed above, the intrinsic ORR activity of atomically precise FeNx is directly linked to the electronic structure of the coordination environment and carbon support, as well as the nature of carbon support [136,191]. The monitoring of the electronic structure of the carbon support changes the pattern of interaction of Fe-Nx active sites [129,153,155]. Regrettably, the alteration in ORR activity of FeNx sites remains exceedingly arduous and demanding, primarily attributable to intricate influencing elements. Some findings have indicated electronic structure of carbon support has a role in influencing the d-band center or d-orbital of Fe active sites [192–194]. However, others have argued that it actually controls the charge state of these sites [195]. Sufficient attempts have been made to investigate and comprehend the FeNx activity description [29,196]. To characterize the ORR activity of the Fe-Nx site, certain factors are typically considered like full width at half maximum of the C1s photo-emission spectrum [197], d-band center [193], and electronegativity of the neighboring atom [29]. However, the description of this phenomenon showed that the orientation dependence and performance of the ORR vary when the same FeNx site was placed on different carbon supports. This variability is challenging to comprehend [13]. Therefore, it is crucial to urgently investigate the underlying reasons for the ORR activity and identify universal indicators for the ORR activity on FeNx sites. An ingenious experiment that proposed the idea of atomically precise single-atom catalysts relies on the deposition and stabilization of isolated nonmagnetic Pt atoms on a FeOx substrate [198]. Similarly, anchoring of a magnetic single atom can be done, and the spin polarization of these atoms imparts the addition of a new dimension to the tuning of the catalytic characteristics of atomically precise M-N-C catalysts [199]. Therefore, the additional effects on these catalysts’ inherent characteristics, including electrical and magnetic structures, can be achieved by modifying their spin states. Recently, changes in the spin states of the core active sites have been studied using different methods to understand how their activity is related to these spin states. For instance, the hybridization between active metal’s 3d orbital and pi* orbital of O2 caused the change in spin states of central active site, correlating the origin of ORR activity. For instance, recently, Lie et al. [200] conducted a theoretical investigation of various fundamental parameters of atomically precise M-N-C materials, and among them, hybridization among Fe-dz 2, 3dyz (3dxz), and O2-π* orbitals is considered to be the basis of ORR activity on Fe-N4 sites, establishing correlation of geometric structure as well as spin states and ORR activity. The models were proposed to establish the origin along with the correlation between the descriptors from the special structure and the extent of frontier orbital, revealing the essential hybridization among Fe(3dz 2), 3dyz (3dzx) and O2-π* orbital related to the height of 3d orbital spatial distribution (Fig. 14 (a–g)). They suggested that the d-band center gap of the spin state (Δd), Fe-site’s magnetic moment (MFe), and *O2 (M*O2) appear to have a close correlation to the ORR performance of the FeN4 site. This study demonstrated new insight into the origin and descriptors of ORR activity on M-N-C catalysts, offering the guidelines for designing high-performance ORR catalysts. Although spin state and their variations affect the catalytic reaction significantly, but the mechanism is yet unclear which prevents rational optimization of catalysis. Hu et al., [201] demonstrated the relation between spin states of active sites along with their catalytic activity considering ORR as an instance, suggesting spin-state dependent on catalytic activity and improvement is possible via adjustment of spin states at the time of catalysis. The possibility of changing the spin state of transition metal by external magnetic field was also studied and the results displayed that optimum catalytic activity could be obtained with the field strength not too strong or not too weak, developing a volcano-like correlation of catalytic activity with field strength (Fig. 14h). In the same line, Zhang et al. [202], revealed that planar Fe2N6 sites display outstanding activity over FeN3 as well as FeN4 sites and *OH hydrogenation step is considered to be potential determining step with 0.415 V overpotential. Origination of ORR activity of Fe2N6 site takes place from low spin magnetic moment leading to high antibonding step as well as the low d-band center of Fe center, further extending to weak binding strength to *OH species (Fig. 14i). This newly developed spin state activity descriptor is not only useful for predicting ORR activity but also shows a correlation with other catalytic activities, suggesting its universal applicability in the future. For instance, very recently, Gong et al. [203] constructed COF-Co, a covalent organic framework (COF) with a single Co atom centered in a porphyrin unit. Their discovery allowed them to control the spin states of individual Co atoms between an HS state and an LS state by logically controlling the Co’s oxidation states. Electroreduction of CO2 to formic acid via the COOH route is more active with Co(III)-TAP in an HS state compared to CoII-TAP in an LS state, according to both investigational and theoretical estimates. Recently, Zhong et al. [204], reported to have prepared single Fe-atoms supported on C2N matrix to facilitate the ORR process. The researchers observed a nearly linear correlation between the activity of the catalyst and the fluctuation of the spin momentum. In a similar way, a unified theoretical and experimental study also documented the spin-activity correlation in a single Co atom facilitated by a TaS2-catalyzed OER process [205]. In the same line, according to ab initio non-adiabatic molecular dynamics simulations conducted by Cheng et al. [206], the photocatalytic water-splitting activity on single Cu-atom@TiO2 could be enhanced by spin selection. Spin-based descriptors offer several advantages compared to previous descriptors, which mostly relied on ionic and adsorption energy models. Spin-based descriptors have a close relationship with the electronic arrangement or spin state of metal active sites. By establishing this connection, researchers may enhance their understanding of traditional theories and effectively regulate the interconnections among structure, electrical properties, and functionality with greater accuracy. A lot of different synthetic methods, such as doping, coordination, compositional, and strain engineering, can make the metallic site reach a high-spin state, which is good for the ORR process [207]. Usually, the existence of an external magnetic field can modify the Zeeman energy, resulting in changes to the spin states of active sites and ORR intermediates [208]. As a result, this process aligns the spin configurations of ions, leading to the formation of a spin channel that enhances the efficiency of catalytic reactions. The intrinsic spin channel of magnetic catalysts enables charge transfer through localized spin moments. The approaches mentioned above allow manipulation of this characteristic [209]. The catalyst’s size can also influence the catalytic process by causing a specific spin state to occur on the surface and/or edge. Moreover, the adsorbent’s impact on the surface magnetic moments and spin states of the catalyst can lead to intricate interactions. Furthermore, the catalytic process often involves surface reconstruction or dynamic local surface phenomena, which might result in variations in spin state. By considering these strategies, catalytic efficiency can be maximized [210]. Although spin plays a crucial role in catalysis, it remains a challenging experimental task to establish methods for improving catalytic performance through spin manipulation remains a challenging experimental task. Specifically, there is currently no explicit description of the spin events involved in catalysis, and the precise mechanism of spin catalysis remains a subject of ongoing debate [211–213]. Therefore, by combining in-situ characterization with theoretical calculation, a more comprehensive understanding of spin-based descriptors may be achieved in the near future. 5 Conclusion and remarks Electrocatalytic ORR, a key and extremely sluggish electrode reaction in FCs and MABs, proceeds via multiple reaction steps with multiple intermediates, requiring inexpensive and efficient electrocatalysts. Due to high atomic utilization along with unusual geometric and electronic configurations, the atomically precise M-N-C catalyst’s family is a good alternative to the pricey Pt-based electrocatalysts. However, it is difficult to balance the adsorption and desorption ORR interactions on the single-atomic active site of these catalysts because of the scaling relationship between the binding energy on the specific site. For diversification and controlling various intermediates separately on active sites, advanced tailoring approaches, including modifications in intersite distance, metal-support as well as metal–metal interactions, coordination environment, and magnetic moment (spin states), have been employed experimentally as well as theoretically. The results demonstrated the remarkable improvement in both the ORR activity and selectivity of atomically precise M-N-C catalysts, indicating that the active sites have always been in a vital position to improve the catalytic theory along with assistance in designing high-profile electrocatalysts under such critical concepts. In recent years, many reports have been available on the development of these tailoring protocols and the rational design of atomically precise M-N-C catalysts methodically, highlighting the electronic and geometric configurations needed to eradicate their weaknesses. Along with discovering many efficient atomically precise M-N-C catalysts under these modifications, the fundamental understanding and in-depth knowledge of the catalytic concept and mode of action have been conceptualized. Regulating the density of active sites in atomically dispersed catalysts is crucial for enhancing electrocatalytic activity, but understanding how individual and interacting sites control catalytic behavior is elusive and requires further research. The origin of the enhancement of catalytic activity towards ORR of atomically dispersed catalysts, especially mono-atomic and dual-atomic M-N-C materials, over intersite distances to sub-nanometer levels, has been discussed. If the distance between the sites is less than 1.2 nm, the electronic structure changes because of the prominent interaction of nearby MNx moieties. This makes the intrinsic ORR performance better. The significant improvement in site performance goes on until neighboring metal atomic sites are as close as 0.7 nm, below which a slight decrease in intrinsic activity is recorded. Moreover, the critical effect of d-site, metal–metal interaction, and coordination environment on atomically dispersed M-N-C-based ORR catalysts has been experimented with integrated approaches, including sophisticated characterization along with theoretical calculations. These effects demonstrate how the ORR performance is altered due to the electronic interaction of adjacent catalytic moieties. Nevertheless, these electrocatalysts still need systematic investigations of the precise impacts of structure on substrate, atomic structure, local coordination, and electronic spin elucidation. In addition, the correct way to construct an activity descriptor for ORR based on the accurate determination of intersite distance, M-M contact, and coordination environment is unclear. In this context, the simulations on the catalysts under operando conditions will surely extend our exploring opportunities for M-N-C-based single-atomic and dual-atomic catalysts, and computational investigations are likely to have a significant role to play in future simulations as well as experiments. New reaction channels are likely to be opened due to the multi-adsorption patterns of O-species on the catalyst’s surface. A rich diversity of catalytic moieties can be brought about by the synergistic actions of isolated active sites’ pairs having appropriate close proximity or intersite distances. The results of theoretical simulations describe the stability of atomically dispersed catalysts quantitatively, which may assist in their atomically precise preparation. The use of a high level of theoretical protocol in the study of atomically dispersed M-N-C catalysts may shed new light in this field. Having considered achievements so far along with further future expected development, the concerned scientific community will agree with the bright light for single-atom catalysis in the years to come. To conduct efficient tailoring of M-N-C materials to improve their activity, ground-breaking strategies involving a potential balance of interaction with different intermediates to break scaling relations are essential. The use of theoretical simulation may be utilized to get an in-depth understanding of the effects of electronic as well as geometric configuration to derive breakthroughs in catalyst design. Therefore, proper design of diverse catalytic sites should be made to obtain the most potential catalysts for O2-electrocatalysis. Dual-atomic M-N-C catalysts having direct metal–metal coordination are assumed to be a suitable replacement for mono-atomic M-N-C catalysts, but their development is practically at the infant stage, in spite of the large number of reports available. Recently, reported work reveals that flexible dual-atom sites undergo simulation, resulting in a new field of extraordinary electrocatalytic activity. In addition, triple or quadruple atom sites with homo- and hetero-nuclear approaches are likely to be another potential design to improve metal loading and exploit synergistic effects. Even though the structure of atomically dispersed M-N-C materials is somewhat easier to understand than that of other similar materials at the nanoscale, it is still very hard to find the main active site with clear geometrical and electronic states. In order to get insight into the nature of active centers, in-situ and ex-situ characterizations are needed using advanced techniques. Although the DFT calculation supported the understanding at the atomic level, the gap between the real situation and the working conditions is still too large. Similar to the fact that the existence of catalytic moieties cannot be ensured without exploiting characterization methods, theoretical simulation is necessary to reveal the mechanism involved in electrocatalytic reactions with M-N-C materials. The purpose of understanding catalytic mechanisms and the structure–activity relationship is to utilize the earned knowledge in designing desirable electrocatalysts. So, the collaboration between experimental and theoretical investigations is obvious in understanding complicated active centers, rational design, and practical application of electrocatalysts in the years to come. In general, the obstacles due to structural inhomogeneity towards the determination of geometric and electronic features of true active sites to establish a structure–activity relationship make M-N-C catalysts suitable to be the ideal platform to make a bridge between simulation and experimentation. Thus, atomically precise M-N-C catalysts should be screened using computations based on first-principle simulation with desirable properties to offer guidelines for conducting experiments. Experimental and simulation-based investigations have shown that rationally adjusting the spin states of the central metal atom in atomically precise M-N-C materials is an effective way to improve their catalytic ORR performance. In this context, various sets of spin states, adjusting the d-electrons or coordination structure of the central metal atom, should be evaluated to find the most stable and effective electronic configuration for rapid electronic communication with paramagnetic O2, facilitating the ORR process. The observations and findings appear to have significant consequences for an in-depth understanding of the mode of action of site density at isolated single-atom sites promoting electrocatalytic activity. Analytical tools and protocols must be developed to develop characterization techniques for these catalysts along with their benchmark assessments. Besides ORR, atomically dispersed M-N-C has displayed activity towards the catalytic promotion of many reactions, like CO2 and N2 reduction. It is anticipated that the modifications in d-site, metal–metal interaction, coordination environment, and spin states will be able to assist in designing efficient, atomically precise catalysts for different catalytic reactions in the future. Moreover, the electrocatalytic processes typically entail the alteration of oxidation states in the core metal atom of M-N-C catalysts. Thus, it is conceivable that the adsorption or desorption of O-species on active sites may cause a change in the spin state of metal sites, resulting in a change in the ion radius of the active site. Consequently, the metal sites may detach from the N-C coordination environment, leading to the formation of clusters or nanoparticles during the ORR process. This can potentially disrupt the intended structure of the catalyst and result in a loss of overall catalytic activity. On the other hand, catalyst reconstruction refers to the regeneration of catalytic active components during the catalytic process, which occurs because of manipulating reaction conditions, altering the type of electrolyte species, or changing the cohesive energy. This phenomenon drives the evolution of two primary divisions: one that focuses on revitalizing inactive or underperforming electrocatalysts by reconstruction, while the other division leverages reconstruction to further enhance the already outstanding performance to an even greater extent. Hence, the development of electrocatalysts should rely on comprehensive reconstructive analysis, and optimization of the bonding and spin states of active sites, resulting in improved activity and stability. Overall, this review article summarises the atomically precise M-N-C materials for ORR, with a special emphasis on intersite distance, M-M, and M-support interactions, MNx-C coordination geometry, and the spin state of the central M-atom. To boost the ORR performance of M-N-C electrocatalyst, two main approaches have been identified: (i) intrinsic properties enhancement of MNx moieties by creating the defect or inseting the hetero-atom dopants or introducing the bi- or multi-metals into the central M-atom coordination sphere; and (ii) M-support electronic communication enhancement via imperfections or hetero-atom dopants to stabilize M-sites and improving the density of M-sites via space confinement tactics. In order to entice future efforts in this era, this review provides an overview of (i) M-N-C materials for O2 electrocatalytic reactions; (ii) activity descriptors; (iii) approaches related to e-transfer, catalytic alterations, and reversible axial ligation; and (iii) ways to modify the intersite distance, M-support and M-M interactions, coordination environment, and spin states. In addition, the logical aspects for the design of advanced M-N-C materials with higher activity as well as selectivity towards ORR could be correlated with traditional as well as new activity descriptors. Moreover, the key issues and potential solutions to understand the structure and performance at the atomic level, as well as the importance of intersite distance, metal–metal interactions, coordination environment, and spin states in the design of future M-N-C catalysts and their mechanistic features, have been covered (Fig. 15 ). Schnadt, J. Condens. Matter Phys., 22 (2010) 472002. Junfeng Huang is currently a lecturer at the School of Mechanical Engineering, Dongguan University of Technology, Dongguan, China. He received his PhD degree from The Hongkong Polytechnic University in 2019. His research focuses on MOF materials synthesis for energy storage and cancer therapy, and flash sintering technology for ceramic materials. Anuj Kumar is working as an Assistant Professor at GLA University, Mathura, India. He received PhD degree in 2017 from Gurukula Kangri University, Haridwar, India. His research focus is on designing of catalytic materials for energy production and storage. He holds good rank in 2% scientist list (by Stanford University) from last three years. He has been awarded by “Young Researcher Award 2020/2021/2022” by InSc and by CEGR. He is serving as Editor (Nano LIFE), Section Editor (Organic Mini Reviews), advisory board member (Carbon Energy), Guest Editor, and editorial board member for various journals. He is also working as an expert consultant for research in various national and international universities. Jianwen Guo is currently a professor at the School of Mechanical Engineering, Dongguan University of Technology, Dongguan, China. He received his PhD degree from The Hunan University in 2010. His research focuses on mechanical manufacturing and reliability. Ghulam Yasin, PI of Research Fund for International Scientists (FRIS) from the National Natural Science Foundation of China (NSFC). His expertise covers the design and development of hybrid devices/technologies of carbon nanostructures and advanced nanomaterials for energy-related and various functional applications for real-world impact. Dr. Yasin has ranked among the world’s top 2% scientists (by Elsevier BV, and Stanford University, USA). He has given more than 20 invited and keynote talks and served as an organizing committee member at international conferences. He serves as an Assessor for the Australian Research Council (ARC), Canberra, Australia, since January 2022. He is also serving as Editor and editorial board member for several international journals.

coredata.dc:description: Inspired by molecular catalysts, researchers developed atomically precise nitrogen-coordinated single or dual metal sites imbedded in graphitized carbon (M-N-C) to fully utilize metallic sites for O2 activation. These catalysts performed remarkably well in the electrocatalytic oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) due to their distinct coordination and electrical structures. Nonetheless, their maximum efficacy in practical applications has yet to be achieved. This agenda identifies tailoring the coordination environment, spin states, intersite distance, and metal–metal interaction as innovative approaches to regulate the ORR performance of these catalysts. However, it is necessary to undertake a precise assessment of these methodologies and the knowledge obtained to be implemented in the design of future M-N-C catalysts for ORR. Therefore, this review aims to analyze recent progress in M-N-C ORR catalysts, emphasizing their innovative engineering with aspects such as alteration in intersite distance, metal–metal interaction, coordination environment, and spin states. Additionally, we critically discuss how to logically monitor the atomic structure, local coordination, spin, and electronic states of M-N-C catalysts to modulate their ORR activity. We have also highlighted the challenges associated with M-N-C catalysts and proposed suggestions for their future design and fabrication.
